dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: I'd love to hear about your experience immigrating in 1965. What was that like for you?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that was quite a journey! I was just 20 years old back then. I remember feeling both excited and nervous. Leaving my home in Italy was hard, but the prospect of new opportunities in America was so enticing.

sentence_annotations.text: Oh, that was quite a journey! I was just 20 years old back then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like it was a really big step to leave everything behind at such a young age. How did you adjust to life in America once you arrived?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it wasn't easy at first. The language barrier was challenging, but I was determined to learn English. I took classes and practiced whenever I could. People were kind, and I found a job as a seamstress in a local shop. That helped me feel more settled and connected.

sentence_annotations.text: leaving my home in Italy was hard
The language barrier was challenging
I found a job as a seamstress

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like finding that job was a significant moment for you. How did your work as a seamstress evolve over time?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, it really was. Working as a seamstress was comforting because it was a skill I brought with me from Italy. Over time, I became more skilled and confident. The shop owners noticed my work and offered me more responsibilities. Eventually, I was involved in some of the decision-making processes, which felt empowering.

sentence_annotations.text: Yes, it really was. Working as a seamstress was comforting because it was a skill I brought with me from Italy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: So when did things change, and you became a union representative?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, that was an interesting turn in my life. It was in the late 70s, I was well into my 30s then. The conditions at the shop were getting tougher, and many of us felt we needed better representation. I was encouraged by my colleagues to step up because I had experience and understood our struggles well. Becoming a union rep allowed me to fight for fair wages and better working hours, which was rewarding.

sentence_annotations.text: Ah, that was an interesting turn in my life. It was in the late 70s, I was well into my 30s then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: That must have been empowering to stand up for your colleagues. What was it like being a union representative?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: It truly was empowering. I felt a strong sense of responsibility because I knew that people were counting on me to advocate for their rights. It was a lot of work, attending meetings and negotiating with the management, but it was also very fulfilling. I learned so much about leadership and the importance of solidarity.

sentence_annotations.text: It truly was empowering. I felt a strong sense of responsibility because I knew that people were counting on me to advocate for their rights. It was a lot of work, attending meetings and negotiating with the management, but it was also very fulfilling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like advocating for your colleagues was a big responsibility. Were there any particular challenges you faced as a union representative?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yes, there were certainly challenges. One of the biggest was negotiating with management. They weren't always receptive to our demands, and sometimes it felt like we were at a standstill. It took a lot of patience and persistence. I also had to balance my work at the shop with my duties as a representative, which was exhausting at times. But every small victory, like securing a pay raise or improving working conditions, made it all worthwhile.

sentence_annotations.text: Oh yes, there were certainly challenges. One of the biggest was negotiating with management. They weren't always receptive to our demands, and sometimes it felt like we were at a standstill. It took a lot of patience and persistence.

I also had to balance my work at the shop with my duties as a representative, which was exhausting at times. But every small victory, like securing a pay raise or improving working conditions, made it all worthwhile.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: That must have been hard. Were there any specific negotiations or victories that stand out in your memory?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, there was one negotiation that I remember vividly. It was around 1982, and the shop owners wanted to cut back on our health benefits. Many of us relied on those benefits, so it was a critical issue. It took weeks of discussions and a lot of back-and-forth, but I managed to secure an agreement that not only maintained our benefits but also improved them slightly. That was a proud moment for me and for the entire team.

sentence_annotations.text: One of the biggest was negotiating with management. They weren't always receptive to our demands, and sometimes it felt like we were at a standstill.
I managed to secure an agreement that not only maintained our benefits but also improved them slightly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: I'd love to hear about how your career transitioned from being a union representative to teaching sewing. What led you to make that change?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, transitioning to teaching was a natural step for me. After many years of being on the front lines advocating for my colleagues, I wanted to share my knowledge and skills with others in a more nurturing environment. I started by offering small classes in my community, showing people the basics of sewing. It was wonderful to see the joy and confidence it brought to others, especially to young people and those who had never sewn before.

sentence_annotations.text: Ah, transitioning to teaching was a natural step for me.
After many years of being on the front lines advocating for my colleagues, I wanted to share my knowledge and skills with others in a more nurturing environment.
It was wonderful to see the joy and confidence it brought to others, especially to young people and those who had never sewn before.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: So when you look back on your journey, from immigrating to becoming a union representative, and then teaching, how do you feel about it all now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Reflecting on my journey fills me with a lot of gratitude and pride. Each phase of my life brought its own challenges and rewards, and I feel blessed to have had the experiences I did. Immigrating to America was daunting, but it opened so many doors for me. Becoming a union representative taught me the value of standing up for what's right and the power of community. And teaching sewing has been such a joy because I get to share a part of myself with others. It’s been a fulfilling life, and I feel content with how things turned out.

sentence_annotations.text: Reflecting on my journey fills me with a lot of gratitude and pride.

Immigrating to America was daunting, but it opened so many doors for me.
Becoming a union representative taught me the value of standing up for what's right and the power of community.
And teaching sewing has been such a joy because I get to share a part of myself with others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: That sounds like a beautiful reflection on your life. How do you feel your work and experiences have impacted your community over the years?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: I like to think that I made a positive impact. In my time as a union representative, I helped improve conditions for my colleagues, which felt like a way of giving back to the community that supported me. And through teaching sewing, I’ve seen so many people gain confidence and joy from learning a new skill. It's heartwarming to see students create something with their own hands, something they can be proud of. I believe that when you share your knowledge and skills, you empower others, and that's a wonderful legacy to leave behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: Before we finish, what final lesson or piece of wisdom would you like to share with those who will hear your story?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: I would say, never underestimate the power of perseverance and kindness. Life can throw many challenges your way, but if you stay true to yourself and treat others with kindness, you'll find your way through. The relationships you build and the knowledge you share are what truly make a life rich. Take the time to listen to others, and don't be afraid to stand up for what you believe in. That's what I've learned, and it's served me well throughout my life.
